headline.main: Tobacco Industry Documents Are Turned Over to Lawmaker

docs.abstract: Hundreds of secret tobacco industry documents divulged in response to Congressional subpoena are turned over to US Repr Thomas J Bliley Jr, longtime industry ally who demanded to see documents before taking any action on proposed $368.5 billion settlement reached in June between five tobacco companies and state attorneys general; may provide broader piture of how companies marketed products to minors and funneled money through lawyers to finance scientific that often downplayed risks of smoking (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of secret tobacco industry documents divulged in response to a Congressional subpoena may provide a broader picture of how cigarette companies marketed products to minors and funneled money through lawyers to finance scientific projects that often played down the risks of smoking. On Friday, four companies, including Philip Morris, the nation's largest cigarette producer, and RJR Nabisco Holdings, the owner of R. J. Reynolds Tobacco, delivered over 800 industry documents to the offices of Representative Thomas J. Bliley Jr., Republican of Virginia.
